Online Free and Reduced Price Meal Applications are now available for the 2020-2021 school year. They can be accessed on our website at: asd1schoolmeals.org or from the school district website under the student nutrition services tab.

If you were approved for Free or Reduced Priced Meals for the 2019-2020 school year, you will need to submit a new application for the 2020-2021 school year. Paper applications will be provided for parents when students return to school. However, the online applications are the most accurate and efficient method to apply for Free or Reduced Priced Meals. We highly encourage all parents to take advantage of this simple to use and fast process.

For more information regarding Free and Reduced Price Meal Applications, please contact the Student Nutrition Services department at 864-847-7344.

Did you know that there are many benefits to teaching our children ASL or American Sign Language? Many states recognize ASL as a foreign language. Studies have shown these skills can raise IQ points as well as helping students in other areas of their schooling. Also, the chance to step in and be of assistance to a deaf or hard of hearing person is a valuable tool to help others. There are many free online resources that can give you more information. This is a great skill to begin to master over the summer.

https://www.parents.com/toddlers-preschoolers/development/language/start-signing-why-kids-should-learn-sign-language/

May 1 at 8:40 AM ·

Please continue to share and like this page so we can connect with as many Wren families as possible. 💙💛💙

We need your help! We need pictures from the old Wren Middle building. This is what we are looking for:
💙 Pictures from 1957-2000 mostly
💛 Any pictures of original construction
💙 More large group picture, than smaller groups of people
💛 Pictures that show aspects of the building: classrooms, gym, cafeteria, lockers, etc.

Please email to Jessica Tollison at tollisonj@apps.anderson1.org

You can scan pictures with a scanner to email or take a quality picture with a cell phone camera. Tips for cell phone pictures of physical pictures:
1. Use good lighting
2. Position the phone/camera to where there is not a glare on a picture from an overhead light.
3. Try to avoid getting other images in the background: desk, tabletop, etc.
4. Email at the highest quality
Note: Don’t take pictures of a computer screen. These do not turn out well. Screenshots do not save at a high quaity. Landscape photos are best for our project.

Pictures must be emailed by Tuesday, May 5 to be included.

post_text: We hope everyone is having a beautiful start to Spring Break. Here is a noon time story for our younger students while they rest from all the fun they are having today. Do you have a Bubble Gum Brain or a Brick Brain? Bubble Gum Brain sounds like it is so much more fun. Let's all remember that little word...YET. What can't we do...yet?
shared_text:
Julia Cook was live.
April 6 at 9:59 AM ·

BECOMING is better than BEING.

I have Bubble Gum Brain. I like to chew on my thoughts, flex, bend and stretch my brain, and expand the way I think! I make great mistakes that help me learn.

I have Brick Brain. With me, things are the way they are...and they're probably not going to change much. I am the way I am...and that's just how it is.

Meet Bubble Gum Brain and Brick Brain: two kids with two VERY different mindsets. Bubble Gum Brain likes to have fun adventures, learn new things, and doesn't worry about making great mistakes. Brick Brain is convinced that things are just fine the way they are and there's not much he can do to change them, so why try?

When Bubble Gum Brain shows Brick Brain how to peel off his wrapper, Brick Brain begins to realize just how much more fun school...and life... can be!

This creative story teaches children (and adults) the valuable lesson that becoming is better than being, which can open the door to a whole new world of possibilities!

Ready, Get Mindset...GROW!!

ASD1 Community: The results of the 2020 Census will help determine how hundreds of billions of dollars in federal funding flow into communities every year for the next decade. The federal funding that ASD1 receives is dependent on accurate census data. This includes funding for school lunches, Title I, Title II, Title IV, Perkins V and other federal programs. Here is a short video explaining about the census: What is the census?

In mid-March, homes across the country will begin receiving invitations to complete the 2020 Census. Once the invitation arrives, you should respond for your home in one of three ways: online, by phone, or by mail. Your personal information is kept confidential. The Census Bureau is bound by federal law to protect your information, and your data is used only for statistical purposes.

Please encourage your family and friends to complete the 2020 Census. For more information please review the attached FAQs page or go to https://2020census.gov/

Please encourage your family and friends to complete the 2020 Census. For more information please review the attached FAQs page or go to https://2020census.gov/
